info.title: getting started
info.text: This example expands on the first CSS animation example. If you haven't already, make sure to check that one out first.

info.title: css animation
info.text: Here I've created a CSS animation called "swing" with three keyframes. The first changes the left value to 40vw (or 40% from the left of our window), the second changes it to 60vw and the last returns it to 40vw.

info.title: left property
info.text: Remember that the left property can only be used if the position property is set. Same is true for top, right, bottom and z-index.

info.title: CSS selector
info.text: In this CSS rule, we're targeting every img element that has an alt attribute set to "cd". This will ensure we don't accidentally apply this CSS rule to other images on our page.

info.title: apply the animation
info.text: It's within this rule that we're applying our animation, in this case with a duration of 4s an easing function of ease-in-out and an iteration count of infinite.

info.title: the images
info.text: This is going to apply the animation to all the CD images we've defined below in our HTML, which by default would look like there was only a single CD on our page, because they'd all be moving together at the same time, each over layed over the other.

info.title: custom classes
info.text: What we've done to make sure they're not over each other is create a unique CSS class for each of the img elements and give each a different top value, this way they line up in a line one above the other.

info.title: animation-delay
info.text: If we'd only assigned a top value then our CD's would move back and fourth together like a single column. So what I've also done is given each class a different animation-delay, which delays the start of the "swing" animation applied to each.

info.title: in closing
info.text: Scattering the delay time by a quarter of a second for each we get more of a snake like swinging effect. Experiment with these values and notice the difference.
